question: Question_01_(e)
sols:
Let's check first the if the integrand goes to 0, as a necessary
condition for convergence.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{i.} $\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} e^{3x} = \infty$
\end{description}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{ii.} $\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} x^{-1} = 0 \checkmark$
\end{description}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{iii.} $\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} x^{-1/2} = 0 \checkmark$
\end{description}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{iv.} $\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} x^{-2} = 0 \checkmark$
\end{description}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{v.} $\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x^2}{1000} = \infty$
\end{description}

This only leaves candidates \emph{ii.}, \emph{iii.}, and \emph{iv.}.

\[\displaystyle \text{Since } x^{1/2} < x < x^2 \text{ we have } x^{-1/2} > x^{-1} > x^{-2} \text{ and thus }\]

\[\int_{1}^{\infty} x^{-1/2}\,dx > \int_{1}^{\infty} x^{-1}\,dx > \int_{1}^{\infty}x^{-2}\,dx\]

Since we are told that only one of the five integrals converges it must
be \emph{iv.}. (E.g., if the integral of \emph{ii.} was finite, and the
integral in \emph{iv.} is less than the integral in \emph{ii.}, then
\emph{iv.} would also necessarily be finite.)

And indeed, \emph{iv.} does converge: By the integral test,

\[\int_{1}^{\infty}x^{-2} \, dx\]

converges if

\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}n^{-2}\]

converges. This sum does converge by the p-series test. \textbf{Hence
the correct answer is \emph{iv.}}.

\emph{As a fun fact,}

\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}n^{-2} = \frac{\pi^{2}}{6}\]
hints:
For an improper integral of the form

\[\int_1^\infty f(x)\,dx\]

to converge it is necessary (but not sufficient) that \emph{f(x)}
approaches 0 as \emph{x} goes to infinity. Check this condition first to
rule out some candidates that do not satisfy this.
For the remaining candidates try the integral test.
